summary: This is a letter from attorney Patrick J. Smith to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding a subpoena issued to the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program in the case of United States v. Maxwell. Smith, representing the program's independent administrator, requests a briefing schedule and an extension to file a motion to quash the subpoena.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the Southern District of New York handling the United States v. Maxwell case. The letter is addressed to her to request a briefing schedule and extension for a motion to quash a subpoena.

persons.name: Patrick J. Smith
persons.context: Attorney from Smith Villazor LLP representing the independent administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program. He is requesting an extension to file a motion to quash a subpoena directed at the program.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Listed among the attorneys copied on the letter, indicating involvement in the case.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Listed among the attorneys copied on the letter, indicating involvement in the case.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Listed among the attorneys copied on the letter, indicating involvement in the case.

persons.name: Mark Stewart Cohen
persons.context: Listed among the attorneys copied on the letter, indicating involvement in the case.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Stemheim
persons.context: Listed among the attorneys copied on the letter, indicating involvement in the case.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier whose estate is implicated. The document references the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program established to resolve claims of sexual abuse against him and his estate.

connections.description: Patrick J. Smith represents the independent administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program, as stated in the letter.
Attorney Patrick J. Smith is formally addressing Judge Alison J. Nathan to request court action regarding a subpoena.

events.title: Filing of Letter Regarding Subpoena
events.description: Attorney Patrick J. Smith files a letter with Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding a subpoena directed at the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program, requesting a briefing schedule and extension to file a motion to quash.

events.title: Government's Motion to Quash Deadline
events.description: The government's motion to quash the subpoena is due, as understood by the letter's author.

events.title: Proposed Motion to Quash Deadline
events.description: The date by which Patrick J. Smith may file a motion to quash the subpoena on behalf of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program, as per the judge's order referenced in the letter.

events.title: Defense Response Deadline
events.description: The date by which the defense in United States v. Maxwell must respond to the government's and the program's motions to quash.

events.title: Requested Extension Deadline
events.description: The date until which Patrick J. Smith respectfully requests an extension to file a motion to quash the subpoena on behalf of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program.

keyFacts: A subpoena under Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 17(c) has been sought by the defendant (Ghislaine Maxwell) and is intended to be authorized by the court, directed at the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program.

The Epstein Victims' Compensation Program is described as an independent, litigation-alternative program established to confidentially resolve claims of sexual abuse against Jeffrey Epstein, his Estate, and other related individuals and entities.

Attorney Patrick J. Smith, representing the program's administrator, requests an extension until November 23, 2021, to file a motion to quash the subpoena, citing recent notice and the complexity of issues.
The government also intends to file a motion to quash the same subpoena, with a deadline of November 17, 2021.
The document is temporarily filed under seal to allow the parties to propose redactions, with any redactions due by November 21, 2021.
